value: I want to come back again to why we're
here and how we got here
the whole idea was that the government
was going to force the opposition to die
on this political hill they did it the
day before the budget knowing that
everyone was distracted by the budget
and they were there was very little
coverage of the use of this nuclear
option by the government in the media
and so that's why the government brought
this if they were hoping that we
wouldn't have enough material and that
we would be afraid of a public backlash
that we were being obstructionist and
that's why their messaging all along has
been oh oh we just want a discussion we
just want to improve things this is
about modernizing we have a mandate to
modernize that's all that's going on
here and yet what they wanted was for us
to cave so that we would quickly get to
a rope on the motion that we will only
make decisions by all party agreement
and it would lose that was their game
plan chair the this this crowd that
wants to everybody to believe that
they're so different and that sunny ways
and we were going to transparency and
accountability and we were all gonna
sing Kumbaya and we're gonna pass laws
together and we would only do theater
all that I'll just talk and now that the
budgets over more and more pundits and
analysts and people are starting to turn
their mind on what's going on and I
haven't seen a positive write-up on the
government's actions yet all the ones
that are starting to turn their mind to
this and look at it and understand in a
serious way what's going on understand
that this is a fight that the government
set up that the government picked that
they were hoping to trouble the rights
and run over run roughshod over the
office the opposition benches and all
they did was unify the opposition's in
opposition to such unfair undemocratic
actions and now they got 7 days to
figure out how to hell to get out of
this mess and then they still got the
problem they started with this they
would like to make some changes to the
house I'm sure they'd like to get a few
advantages
but some of it may actually be goodwill
but now the thing is such a mess that
look where they are this is what happens
when you say you're gonna be one way and
you act another this government talked
up a democratic reform argument that was
as good as anything the NDP or the
Greens could come up with and the proof
of that is the number of seats that you
got in the election but actions like
this on how we pass laws are so opposite
to what every member of the Liberal
caucus said during the campaign and what
their Prime Minister has said I don't
know where the government goes now but
they need a stand down and mr. Simms mr.
Richards and I and I think you're left
tried night and day literally in the
middle of the night having side meetings
with you we've been the ones giving
suggestions to you to give to the
government about how we can get out of
this we've done everything we can to be
reasonable to get out of this quagmire
because there is some good work we'd
like to get to it just got a whole lot
tougher for the government to get out of
this because you think that you can do
this to us and then just decide you're
gonna fall sorry Chuck sorry we didn't
mean to upset you later we got a little
crazy there sorry we'll go back to our
sunny ways no this does damage does
damage to your brand it does damage to
this relationship and the one chance
you've got to salvage is how you decide
to create your exit ramp and your exit
strategy under this boondoggle and your
government has been so vicious in this
process that it's getting harder and
harder to find an amicable way down and
I can only urge the government to
reconsider how they're approaching this
because if the government thinks that
they're gonna double down when we come
back and that somehow we're gonna get
weaker in our opposition then they once
again misread this situation we get
stronger by the day mr. Richards is read
out the kind of support that's starting
to come in across the country as people
realize what this what this government's
trying to do to unilaterally on
power grab changed the way laws are made
in our Parliament that that's what's at
stake that's what's going on and the
rights of the minority and everything
all of these things are at stake and so
chair I I can only I will conclude by
only hoping the government when they
when they create their exit strategy
because I can't believe you're gonna
double down on this you you can't be
that politically tone-deaf as to say
okay well that the reason that didn't
work was we weren't tough enough
we weren't nasty enough we weren't
vicious enough we weren't tricky enough
hopefully that's not the attitude what
we need is a whole different attitude
and an approach that takes us back to
where we were as quickly as possible
from this viciousness and back to
getting and working together as we were
and we were going to on Tuesday again I
end by saying the government started
this fight but let me tell you the
opposition United will end it the only
question is when and how much more
damage to the government brand in the
process
